comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Frank Case was an American hotelier and author. He owned and managed the Algonquin Hotel during the heyday of the Algonquin Round Table and wrote a number of books about his experiences with the hotel and the Round Tablers. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Case William DeWolf Hopper (March 30, 1858 – September 23, 1935) was an American actor, singer, comedian, and theatrical producer. Although a star of the musical stage, he was best-known for performing the popular baseball poem Casey at the Bat. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeWolf_Hopper en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Golden_Theatre

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
De Wolf Hopper was the husband of Hedda Hopper, an actress who became famous in her later years as a newspaper columnist chronicling the foibles of Hollywood luminaries. Their son, the actor William Hopper, played Natalie Wood's father in the James Dean movie, "Rebel Without a Cause." Later he played Perry Mason's assistant, Paul Drake, on a long-running TV series.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: George Mooser seems to have been a Broadway producer. See www.ibdb.com/person.php?id=22031 Also, according to www.emovieposter.com/agallery/archiveitem/11154322.html with United Artists (around 1920) protecting copyright movies against "film pirates" in the far east. See also The Evening News - Jul 3, 1922 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1982&dat=19220703&... for a report of his success.

comment._content: More information on John Golden (1874-1955), also a Broadway producer: www.imdb.com/name/nm0325444/bio

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content: Thanks everyone for the additional information. This photo was taken outside of the Lambs Club like one of the others Wystan linked to. I found it interesting that this building now houses a restaurant called the Lambs Club but is no way associated with the actual Lambs Club which is now headquartered in another building.
